American Beauty is a timeless masterpiece that explores the complexity of the human psyche and the emptiness of suburban life. Directed by Sam Mendes and written by Alan Ball, this film is a true cinematic gem that offers a profound and thought-provoking meditation on the nature of existence.

The story follows Lester Burnham, a middle-aged man who is stuck in a loveless marriage, trapped in a soul-crushing job, and alienated from his teenage daughter. However, everything changes when he becomes infatuated with his daughter's friend, Angela, and starts to embrace a rebellious and carefree lifestyle.

Kevin Spacey delivers a stunning performance as Lester, capturing the character's vulnerability, frustration, and longing with impeccable precision. The supporting cast is equally impressive, with Annette Bening as Lester's neurotic and controlling wife, Chris Cooper as the homophobic and abusive neighbor, and Thora Birch as Lester's troubled daughter.

What makes American Beauty truly exceptional is its ability to blend humor, drama, and social commentary in a seamless and captivating way. The film is filled with memorable scenes and poignant moments that stick with you long after the credits roll, from Lester's iconic "I'm just an ordinary guy with nothing to lose" monologue to the haunting image of a plastic bag floating in the wind.

Overall, American Beauty is a cinematic masterpiece that deserves every bit of praise it has received over the years. It's a must-watch for anyone who appreciates great filmmaking, complex characters, and deep philosophical themes. If you haven't seen it yet, do yourself a favor and watch it as soon as possible. You won't regret it.

Sam Mendes' "American Beauty" is an intimate, heartfelt and deeply thought-provoking drama about the unseen beauty of American suburban life. With his directorial debut, director Sam Mendes crafted an unforgettable drama about a dysfunctional family in the midst of a mid-life crisis. It's the filmmaker's first attempt to humanize the lives of suburban American families, but he pulls it off seamlessly. Using captivating cinematography, Mendes draws viewers into the world of a middle-aged man that is stuck in a mid-life crisis. For a first-time filmmaker, Mendes shows exceptional control over the storytelling, technical aspects and performances. Alan Ball's screenplay is also sensational, and expertly uses clever voice-over narration to put viewers into the mindset of an unhappily married father. It is hard to not admire the astonishing performances from the cast. Kevin Spacey delivers one of the best performances of his career as Lester Burnham. With mesmerizing expressions, he conveys the droll humor, loneliness and sexual frustrations of a middle-aged man that struggles to mend his broken family. The supporting cast, which includes the scene-stealing Annette Benning, is also excellent and worthy of recognition. Although "American Beauty" remains a powerful drama, ultimately it is not a flawless film. If there's a minor drawback to the movie, it often struggles to find a consistent tone. The film switches back and forth between moments of satirical humor and darkness, never quite achieving a balanced tone. Nevertheless, fans of family dramas will definitely enjoy "American Beauty" and so will movie-goers seeking evocative entertainment. At a time when Kevin Spacey remains a controversial public figure in Hollywood, it's a beautiful reminder that an actors' filmography is worth separating from his tarnished public reputation.

Sam Mendes' "American Beauty" is absolutely, positively one of the most unique films I've watched in a very long time. Mesmerizing, humorous, titillating, dramatic, and suspenseful, "American Beauty" is one of those rare films that genuinely works on multiple levels - and for that it rightfully earned its positive critical reception and its slew of Oscars. 

The movie stars Kevin Spacey as Lester, a miserable middle-aged man who is not respected by anybody - especially not his wife Carolyn (Annette Bening) and teenage daughter, Jane (Thora Birch). Having been trapped in a loveless marriage for the past several years, Lester can't help but take an interest in his daughter's attractive friend, Angela (Mena Suvari). He begins to experience a series of risqué fantasies involving her, and her naturally flirty personality only perpetuates them. It soon becomes apparent that this newfound attraction has not only increased his sex-drive, but also provided him with the motivation to reclaim the good life he once had... and so begins the transformation of Lester Burnham. 

But the movie doesn't focus solely on Lester; it branches out, giving a decent amount of attention to the character of Jane and her romantic encounters with Ricky (Wes Bentley), a boy living next-door to her. While he initially appears creepy and off-putting, Jane can't help but detect that there is something about him she finds appealing, so she gets to know him better. She learns that he certainly has some issues, but also has an empathetic, sensitive side of which she was hitherto unaware. 

All of the aforementioned parts are played brilliantly by their respective actors. The most notable performance being Spacey's, as he manages to portray Lester as a likable underdog whilst also showing us his aggression, concupiscence, nihilism and volatility. It is made abundantly clear that there are no perfect characters in this story; they all have major flaws, and I can imagine most viewers will find at least one that, to some extent, resonates with them. 

I feel like I have a lot more to say about "American Beauty," and I've been trying to  gather and organize the rest of my thoughts for quite some time now, but I've concluded that it's pointless. There's no way in which I can describe it in words without doing it an injustice. This movie is something special because it's more than a movie - it's an experience... and some experiences are simply beyond words.

"American Beauty" , written by Alan Ball, is a disturbing and engrossing film that pulls apart the American dream of middle class families and their lifestyle.  Ball uses symbolism, lighting, and each of the characters words and actions in order to explore different issues found within American society. Like other dramas "American Beauty" tackles and dramatizes the issues within what is considered to be the "American Dream". However, it uses each of the characters and their relationships to others in order to represent these certain issues. For example, Lester Burnham represents missed opportunities and unhappiness within his everyday life. Jane represents unhappiness with her physical appearance and her parent relationship.  Overall, I would give this film a rating of 3/5 stars. This is because while I enjoyed the symbolism and the issues pointed out about the American lifestyle it also normalizes these issues and portrays them as though they are nothing to fix or be ashamed of. Furthermore, this film dramatizes these issues and the main source of the main character development is a sexual fantasy about his daughters' best friend. However, this film had many memorable quotes and important lessons within it.  The film uses the color red in order to symbolize desire and overcome with passion and emotion. Rose is a common thread within the film as well. Used to indicate fantasy and passion. Rose can also mean secrecy within the film. The plot of the film moves notably slow until the last 15 minutes which are packed with twists and turns. However, the ending really gives the movie meaning and draws together what the movie had been showing the whole time. Like other parent-child conflict archetype's, this movie centers around unhealthy and struggling relationships. However, it adds complexity to each character showing the underlying issues and connections in all of the characters. All in all, "American Beauty" tears apart the fantasy of the American lifestyle.

American Beauty is as much about having different viewpoints on love as it is about a dysfunctional family's desire for a re-awakening. In the beginning, Lester (Kevin Spacey), Carolyn (Annette Bening), and Jane Burnham (Thora Birch) are trapped in a drab, hollow, and mundane suburban world where appearances are worshiped. Carolyn has locked her family up in her dungeon of high class success and magazine cover luxury. Later on, Lester escapes that society by quitting his job and falling in love with Angela (Mena Suvari), Jane's best friend. Jane yearns for her true self, so she hooks up with Ricky (Wes Bentley), the "creepy guy with the camera," who has found inner beauty. Frank Fitts (Chris Cooper), Ricky's father, represses his past as a Marine and keeps his true homosexual self in the closet. Whether the choices Lester makes are uncomfortable or inappropriate, Carolyn's quick and shallow, or Jane's strange and confused, both characters' actions are based on the theme of self-acceptance dominating appearance. Also, the fact that both characters have different perspectives on beauty helps guide them to their desires, even if it is a videotape featuring a plastic bag caught in the wind. American Beauty is a harrowing film and one of Sam Mendes's best. It figures that his directorial debut feature is impressive, as well as audacious.

I expected to love this film and I did, in between the awfulness of Dances with Wolves (1990) and Going My Way (1944) it was wonderfully refreshing to see a good, well made film that deeply explores modern sexual mores and family dynamics. Unfortunately the film is mired in controversy due to the presence of lead actor Kevin Spacey and although I am completely against the actions that he took in his personal life I would still urge people to watch this film because outside of Spacey it contains really great writing, direction and performances. Sam Mendes made his feature film directorial debut with this and I would have to say that this is my favorite of the films he has directed so far as he seems more focused here and deals with interesting characters going through mundane lives. I found the entire two hours to be highly entertaining but the ending to be emotionally affecting and I was surprised that I found it in myself to love these characters.

Lester Burnham, Kevin Spacey, is going through a mid-life crisis that has been spurred on by his meeting Angela, Mena Suvari, the attractive friend of his teenage daughter. He and his wife Carolyn, Annette Bening, have a strained relationship and he can't connect with his daughter Janie, Thora Birch, who has begun a relationship with her neighbor, drug dealer Ricky Fitts, Wes Bentley. Burnham quits his job, makes several purchases on expensive items and starts working out but as Fitts' abusive father Frank, Chris Cooper, directs his anger at Lester it is clear that it will all end in tragedy.

Seeing a film set in a vaguely recognizable setting and featuring characters that I could relate to in at least some way was a huge relief. Burnham's actions are not endorsed as he is mostly mocked or pitied by the film for his childish and creepy desire for a teenage girl, his letting go of all responsibility and his treatment of those around him. Carolyn is also seen as an uptight and difficult to live with woman and Bening is great at making you root against her but she becomes humanized by the end of the film and her faults are understandable. The relationship between Janie and Ricky was also accurate to how a certain type of socially isolated teenager would fall for an equally discontented youth. Even the seemingly shallow and manipulative Angela is revealed to be vulnerable as she searches for approval in lascivious older men and is desperate not to be â~ordinary'.

The screenplay contains several great scenes but in particular I enjoyed the attempted reconciliation of Lester and Carolyn and the plastic bag scene. We are lead to believe that the Burnhams will be able to rekindle the love and passion in their relationship as they kiss on the couch but their canoodling is cut short by Carolyn as she asks Lester to put his beer down for fear of it staining the couch. Lester then yells at her about how materialistic she is but this belies his hypocrisy as he has bought an unnecessarily flashy car and purchased several items that he has valued over Carolyn. The plastic bag scene is all about living in the moment and being able to appreciate the beauty of everyday life no matter how small a form it comes in. Bentley delivers his lines as Ricky as though he's in a sort of trance, much like Allison Janney as his mother, with a complete lack of caring about how anybody else feels about the moment he had.

All of the performances were great, including unfortunately Spacey. Bening carries off moments that would seem terribly pantomime-y in the hands of other actresses and watching she and Spacey square off is terrific fun. Cooper is truly fantastic though as the scene in which he confronts Lester then attempts to become emotionally intimate with him was devastating as the at first relieved then shocked, humiliated and angered expressions on his character's face convey all we need to know. Cooper makes us feel bad for a man who abuses those around him and shows us all of the horror that repressed sexuality can wreak on a man's life.

Throughout watching American Beauty, I kept wondering to myself, HOW DID THIS MOVIE GET BEST PICTURE WTFFFF. I'm not saying it's a bad movie, because it's not, but I don't think this movie is a masterpiece as some people have said. He does reckless and foolish things in this movie, but he doesn't deceive himself; he knows he's running wild--and chooses to, burning up the future years of an empty lifetime for a few flashes of freedom. I found myself liking this movie right off the bat: the opening sequence, wherein the main protagonist Lester Burnham (portrayed by the ever-so-believable Kevin Spacey) uses self-deprecating irony to describe the incentive that'll eventually lead him into a fatal midlife crisis. From there on, "American Beauty" only kept me captivated throughout its full playback.

Firstly, let me tackle the cinematography, as it's not enormously spectacular - although far above-average, if you ask me. Mendes & Hall did a great job at making nearly every shot one worth admiring (or, at least, appreciating): in light of this, one of the characters, namely one of Lester's neighbours, uses a consumer-grade 90s digital camera to film the activity around the protagonist's house in a fairly amateurish though certainly voyeuristic way, providing a unique point of view.
This furthermore describes the rest of the scenes and accompanying sound design: unique. Especially as Lester fantasises about one of his daughter's friends Angela, the scenes have a concise aesthetic vibe to them, albeit oftentimes coated in the film's eerie, dramatic self-awareness. The repeating of some compositions throughout the film to clarify the changes the characters have undergone, is a very nice touch to all of this, as well as the ending sequence making heavy use of gratuitous Hollywood-rainfall.

Moving on to the story, I think it's clear by now that the movie gets the majority of its credit for exactly that. What comes to mind when trying to best describe the plot, are "intricate", "existential" and "intriguingly thought-out", all three with good reason: the Lolita-esque and thereby sexually open narrative paves the way for incredibly fine character construction, with Kevin Spacey once again performing like none other.
That is: Lester starts off as being a boring office worker, tired with life, far from daring to speak up for himself. American Beauty takes a whole new look at the American Dream. While I can agree that Kevin Spacey did an amazing job in his role as Lester Burnham, I think this film is grossly overrated. It makes its social and moral commentary much to overt for my enjoyment.
 
I also could not wrap my mind around the character Lester's arch. He goes from an average guy with a boring monotonous life to an anti-hero willing to engage in sexual activity with his daughter's best friend as well as blackmail his wife. It's not that this character arch was unbelievable, but more that it was unsatisfying. To me it was an attempt on the writer's part to make the film as edgy and biting as possible, while sacrificing the story line in the process.

Another point of discontent was the rose thread, which symbolized lust and passion. I felt it was too overt for the viewers. There is no element of this film that is difficult or trying to grasp; it is all very in your face, leaving nothing for the viewer to ponder as they leave the theater or walk away from the screen.
 
I did appreciate the methods used in the film that contributed to the cinematography as a whole. The use of the mundane sounding elevator tunes throughout the movie conveyed the boring nature of the average American life beautifully and was a marvelous thread that stayed consistent up until Lester was shot. The sameness conveyed early in the film by the sets matching the characters' outfits was also a choice I appreciated that further exemplified the theme of monotony.
 
Although some elements of the film did contribute to some enjoyable moments, overall I believe it was not as great a movie as others believe it to be due to overreaching on the writer's part to give it immense shock value, although it did convey an important social message in the end.

Of course, such things don't occur unless you're intolerant, self-centered, and stuck in a thankless job - but the movies have proven to me time and time again that, once you hit your late 30s, early 40s, things aren't as much "I Love Lucy" as they are "Happiness." My immediate family has proven to me that a wife and kids can be a good thing so long as you work hard and treat everyone right, but stopping my probably-not-there concerns about the future isn't much of a possibility.
	Movies that further my anxieties follow the norm made by "American Beauty," which wonders aloud if apparently having it all is as great of a thing as it's cracked up to be.  What if you do everything right in your life and still find yourself looking for a deeper meaning? An extraordinary (and extraordinarily funny) inside look at the pitfalls that dampen the cinematic trope of the mid-life crisis, it is a massively intelligent film that finds a dark humor in the trivial tragedies of suburban life.
	It depicts the currently (and perhaps everlastingly) dejected life of an all-American family, a Nuclear one that surrounds their picture-perfect home with a white picket fence and a stunningly red coat of roses.  Pop, Lester (Kevin Spacey), is trapped in a boring job at an advertising agency; his wife, Carolyn (Annette Bening), is a struggling realtor with a winning smile and a bad habit of breaking down in soap operatic tears the minute something doesn't go her way; their daughter, Jane (Thora Birch), is so perpetually ignored that she's saving up for a boob job just so she can get attention from someone.  They all hate each other - but it wasn't always that way, and that makes "American Beauty" more heartbreaking that we would like to admit.  
	None of their lives have much direction, so when Lester looks out into the world and catches a glimpse of Angela (Mena Suvari), Jane's best friend, at a cheerleading event, it's like a miracle: he finally has a purpose in his life, which is to impress, and maybe even seduce, the young, sexy blonde, though not realizing just how stupid, and creepy, that is.  
	As he descends into an existence that seems to revolve only around "looking good naked," Carolyn and Jane's problems simultaneously escalate.  Carolyn starts having an affair with her rival realtor (Peter Gallagher) and passes the time at the local gun range, and Jane decides to take up a relationship with the kid who just moved in next door (Wes Bentley), who obsessively films everything he sees, who is a pathological liar, and who is a drug dealer on the side.
	We have a feeling that they all know that these hopes of validation will lead to nowhere, that their lives are a mess in the ways members of the suburbs can only understand, but it doesn't stop them from attempting to stop going through the motions and sin their way back to the top.  The film ends in a death, and we know this immediately as "American Beauty" starts - Spacey's narration comes from beyond the grave - but that isn't what drives the film.  What drives it is its relatability, and how true it feels when peering through the looking glass of the American Dream.  It's the American dream after the happy ending washes away and reality sets in.
	The film is the directorial debut of Sam Mendes, who has gone on to make such classics as "Road to Perdition" and the latest two James Bond films.   "American Beauty" brings nuance and uncomfortably successful humor to a plot that we've seen many times before; it is the crown jewel of the mid-life-crisis movie, with Spacey (pathetic), Bening (piercing), Birch (scared), and Suvari (seductive) leading the way with indelible performances.  
	I still have no doubt that the 1970s, along with the '90s, are the best decades in cinema.  Most of their classics are small, character-based, talky, moving, original.  "American Beauty," which arrived at the end of the era, is one of its most heartfelt.  We know its characters - we've passed them on the streets, we've made small talk with them.  Once we see life through their eyes for two hours, we understand them.

The definition of a dark comedy is a film that makes humor out of gloomy satire and serious situations. "American Beauty" is a dark comedy, yes, but it's not like any other one out there. A film like "Fargo" takes very serious subject matter that we are able to laugh at because of the behavior of the characters. "American Beauty" is different, there's a wall built between its comedic and dramatic elements, one the audience is easily aware of. 

In "American Beauty", we laugh because we can relate, and because of the very strong sarcasm of the characters. Kevin Spacey and Annette Bening were definitely the perfect choices for their characters. They're an unhappy married couple with a teenaged daughter, and it's only when Lester (Spacey) sees his daughter's beautiful friend at a basketball game, that he feels young again, and motivated to change from his usual, boring self. 

At times, it's an uneasy film to watch, but it's always wonderful, even when it's a little uncomfortable. It sounds like this makes no sense at all, but it does, and you'll understand what I'm talking about if you've seen the film. Scenes in which Lester and Carolyn are arguing, are supposed to be funny because of their sarcasm, however, it's still understood as a serious scene. We aren't making fun of them, and we're not laughing down at them, we're making humor out of a serious situation, but it's understandable and obvious, and it doesn't diminish the scenes from their seriousness.

There are moments like that, and there are moments that are meant to be relaxed and serious. I was always intrigued at how, without thinking, the audience knows when a scene should be funny and when a scene is serious. This is done because of the outstanding performances from the whole cast and the wonderful script. 

The story in "American Beauty" is layered, and the title works perfectly. Lester is intrigued by the beauty of his daughter's (Thora Birch) friend Angela (Mena Suvari). He is motivated for the first time in many years, and his descriptions of these feelings, and some wonderfully shot dream sequences, are excellent. The "beauty" he is referring to is merely physical beauty. The tagline of the film is "look closer", which suggests that outer beauty is NOT what the film is referring to. Or is it? In a way, I believe it's about both. 

Jane is unhappy with her looks, and doesn't feel happy in her own skin, especially with her friend Angela who is always talking about how many times she has had sex. When a new neighbor moves in, she is both slightly creeped out and slightly curious when he begins filming her. Another fantastic scene is when Angela is in Jane's room, and begins dancing in the window when Ricky (Wes Bently), the new neighbor, is filming. He looks right past Angela and directly at Jane. This scene is the first time there is a focus on inner beauty. 

All of the characters in the film find their own definition of "American Beauty". It's a wonderful depiction of an exaggerated family life in America. It's one of the few films with such a brilliant line between drama and comedy. It works as both wonderfully.

The more I thought about it after I watched the more I continued to admire it. It is a film of so many elements, so many subtexts, all of them so brilliantly done, that to say that the film is about one thing doesn't do service to how many layers are in this film. American Beauty is a film that defies any one explanation. On the surface it's about Lester Burnham deciding to change his life dramatically after becoming sexually obsessed with a teenage girl. Meanwhile his wife is desperately trying to sustain the facade of her perfect life, and his daughter's problems are basically ignored by the two of them. Below the surface it is a portrait of the darkside of American suburbia, ancriticism of the facades and lies that people construct around themselves, an attempt to find all the small beauties that exist in our world, and much more. The genius of this film is that's its able to weave all these elements, themes, and subtexts into a cohesive and satisfying story. It manages to hold all this together, while still being both very tragic, strangely uplifting, and darkly, darkly comic. Meanwhile every actor onscreen is completely brilliant. It is an exceptionally well-acted film, with every single character becoming unique human beings. American Beauty is one of those rare films where you don't see the A-list actors instead of the human characters onscreen. You begin to emphasize and fall in love with these characters, warts and all. Any flaw I can find with this film would be absolute nit-picking. A family moves in next door, a retired Maine Colonel Frank Fitts (Chris Cooper) his wife, Barbara (Allison Janney) and their teenage son, Ricky (Wes Bentley). Ricky smokes and sells weed.  Frank and Ricky do not get along.  Lester becomes obsessed with Angela (Mena Suvari), his daughters cheerleading friend. Carolyn is having an affair with Buddy (Peter Gallagher) a fellow real estate agent.  
      The Production design was amazing.  The costumes were perfect for each character. Lester wearing track suits. Ricky dressing neat to not upset his father but also hip enough to look different.  The setting of the film could have been any major american city. The homes were the perfect suburbia. Even the fast food restaurant that Lester takes a job at was a perfect location. The Design of the film was also well executed. For example the lighting in the film evoked a kind of somber beauty. I especially liked the scenes when Lester is fantasizing about Angela.
      American Beauty is a modern day classic. One may even say masterpiece. Considering the fact it was Sam Mendes first film, the accomplishment is astonishing. The performances are brilliant. Bening and Spacey really stand out and deserved all the awards recognition they received. The younger actors are the glue that holds the piece together. Bentley, Birch, and Suvari all shine here. There is even some CGI used very subtly to enhance and forward the story.  I was struck by the true beauty of the cinematography. Mendes ability to frame his shots perfectly at every crucial moment is inspiring. This is a refreshing break from hollywood blockbusters.

Not soon after, all of our sympathy is challenged when the switch is flipped, and his lust is reawakened by a cheerleader. One who is best friend's with his own daughter. From there on out, he speaks hatefully to those he encounters, he shamefully lusts after his daughter's best friend. And this breaks us. This nearly perfect drama demonstrates how films are meant to be made. Throughout American Beauty, we see intricate layers of tension among several characters as well as a strangely sincere portrayal of airy sarcasm that is witty and clever enough to make this movie rewarding even if viewed simply for its comedy. While the characters and families often seem totally absurd, they are shockingly believable representations of some of the absurdity we see throughout much of society today.

Often films and works of literature in general have a tendency to focus on a single character. We find one well developed personality with great depth surrounded by simple characters placed around the protagonist simply to aid the development of the protagonist. In American Beauty, Alan Ball has successfully created the illusion of entire very real families not only by creating several realistic characters, but by compounding interactions between all of them together in an elegant dancing network of personalities.

This interplay allows us to relate to every single character because we see where each of their personalities come from. It forces us to think of social ethics in a new light because we find that every individual is partly responsible for how the group constantly shapes all of the individuals within it. There is no simple answer for "Who is to blame?" What are we even blaming them for when there are so many factors that go into each individual's emotional state? By revealing the confusing nature of these questions, Alan Ball helps answer some difficult questions about society.

No other film I have seen has been so successful of accomplishing a personality interplay like this with so many characters at once, and this combined with its great comedy is why I award American Beauty with my rating of 5/5 stars that I reserve only for films that I consider to be the best of the best.

"American Beauty" - An American masterpiece

Lester Burnam: It's hard to stay mad, when there's so much beauty in the world. 

It's great when a movie can pull you in, show you characters that you come to know and care for, and change your emotions based on what happens to these characters. "American Beauty" does just that. At some of the most important times in their lives, we learn about the colorful personalities of these people. They all have beauty, something that pulls the audience in. We sympathize with them, we like to know about them. 

I'm most intrigued by the performance that Kevin Spacey gives. He's so believable, so perfectly sarcastic when he speaks during the humorous moments of the film, and so pathetic, but I like our protagonist. Come to think of it, every character has a likable aspect, but the things they hide from us, the things hidden underneath, can come out at any moment, and they're unexpected. 

Not only is "American Beauty" a brilliant dramatic picture that has us caring for the characters, it's also a successful comedy, and effortless at that. Naturally, some of these characters, especially Lester (Spacey) and Carolyn (Bening), are often sarcastic. It could seem awkward, it could be questionable, but it's not like that. I was never wondering whether or not a certain part was meant to be funny, it just is, and it works.

It's a comedy that is able to take itself seriously, and stay serious throughout its entirety. I've actually never seen a movie shift so quickly and easily from being incredibly dramatic and emotional to being a movie that seems to have some humor. 

Having said all of this, I believe "American Beauty" is easily one of the greatest films about family, marriage, and especially beauty. The beauty and the beast. We see both here. We see lies, betrayal, depression, relationships, love, and friendship, appear, disappear, only to reappear. I loved it. The best film of the year.
